Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Education Development Center, Inc. (EDC) and partners serve as the resource center for the ITEST program and community. This new iteration of the Learning Resource Center is re-named the STEM Learning and Research Center (STELAR) to represent the growing need to broaden the existing Community of Practice and share lessons learned with an increasingly diverse field of stakeholders. Among various other accomplishments in its nine-year tenure leading the LRC, EDC has provided leadership in building a thriving and highly engaged community of ITEST PIs, project staff and evaluators, developed a well-regarded model of technical support and programmatic resource center infrastructure, raised the national visibility of the ITEST program and the collective impact of its grantees, and helped disseminate key project findings to the field through data briefs, public webinars, and working group activities. The STELAR team brings their collective expertise in capacity building, broadening participation, and career development to this new work. That team is enriched through a new partnership with the EdLab Group, an educational equity non-profit organization, who brings considerable expertise to this work, in particular through the National Girls Collaborative Project. EdLab Group is involved in the implementation of key dissemination and outreach activities leveraging their experience developing national networks and collaborative dissemination models, and their extensive connections to broadening participation communities. In addition, EdLab Group has primary responsibility for the social media work of STELAR as it supports and deepens the technical support, dissemination and outreach work.

This partnership builds upon past EDC successes, leverages wider networks and connects with audiences who are not currently aware of ITEST. Together, EDC and EdLab Group capitalize on the vibrant ITEST Community of Practice already developed and the existing knowledge base of the ITEST program to expand efforts in new directions that build on what has been learned, develop new relationships, and broaden outreach to targeted stakeholders. STELAR focuses on three primary areas of work, namely: 1) Facilitating projects' success through timely, high quality technical support and monitoring of projects throughout their implementation lifecycle; 2) Informing and influencing the field of STEM/ICT education practitioners and researchers, industry and policy stakeholders by disseminating project findings nationally; and 3) Deepening the impact and reach of the ITEST program by broadening participation to areas and institutions not currently represented in the ITEST portfolio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The challenge of preparing youth for changing workplace environments calls for new innovations in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education. The National Science Foundation (NSF) Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program addresses this challenge by funding research and development on the design of learning experiences that increase student awareness of STEM occupations and motivate them to pursue education pathways to STEM occupations, typically engaging business and industry partners to better ensure that PreK-12 experiences foster the knowledge and skill-sets needed for emerging STEM occupations.  Funding for the ITEST program is provided by revenue from the H-1B visa program, which permits overseas workers to fill vacant U.S. STEM positions.

The STEM Learning and Research Center (STELAR) at Education Development Center (EDC) was established in 2012 to support the ITEST program in meeting its goals.  STELAR continued the work of EDC’s ITEST Learning Resource Center (LRC), which supported ITEST projects from 2003-2011. STELAR has worked to build capacity of ITEST projects and expand the impact of the ITEST program through:

  1. Technical support that facilitates ITEST projects’ success in developing and articulating innovative models for STEM learning environments;
  2. Synthesis and dissemination of ITEST projects’ findings nationally in order to inform and influence a national community of other stakeholders;
  3. Outreach efforts to broaden participation in the ITEST community to individuals from organizations and communities not currently represented in the ITEST portfolio.

Since 2012 STELAR hosted 3 annual Summits for the ITEST community of projects, facilitated 10 topical interest groups, provided approximately 50 one-on-one technical assistance events, coordinated 20 conference presentations, published 40 products or publications, led 4 proposal development workshops at MSIs, presented 6 conference presentations at national meetings designed to broaden participation in the ITEST portfolio, developed and piloted the first-of-its kind NSF proposal development online course, and developed a website (http://stelar.edc.org) with regularly updated content and interactive space for ITEST grantees to encourage exchange among projects.   

STELAR has worked diligently to synthesize and disseminate program findings across the portfolio of funded projects in order to inform STEM education and workforce development research nationally.  Examples of STELAR’s national dissemination/publication of ITEST program findings include:

  • Workforce Education Models for K-12 STEM Education Programs: Reflections on, and Implications for, the NSF ITEST Program, by David Reider, Kirk Knestis, and Joyce Malyn-Smith, which proposes a STEM workforce education logic model tailored to the particular context of the ITEST program, grounded in prior conceptual frameworks developed by ITEST teams. (2015) 
  • ITEST Special Issue of the Journal of Science and Technology (JOST) ‘Stories from ITEST – Culturally Competent Projects that Inspire Young People to Pursue STEM careers’ co-authored by STELAR and 16 ITEST projects. (2016)
  • Building the foundational skills needed for success at work at the human technology frontier which details the role of the ITEST program in preparing students for the future of work, where technology will shape human interaction, and where technologies and humans will collaborate to discover and innovate. (2017)

In addition to serving ITEST projects and the NSF since its inception, STELAR and its website http://stelar.edc.org became an available resource for national, state and local education departments seeking to strengthen STEM education, as well as individuals and organizations interested in improving STEM education for youth.  STELAR offered models, lessons learned, and expertise gained from EDC’s close to 14 years’ of support of the ITEST program.

Since 2004, the ITEST program has invested approximately $382 million in 344 projects located in 46 states and the District of Columbia.  As of 2017, the ITEST program has reached 566,500 youth, 16,900 educators, and 6,800 parents & caregivers. Combining the best of formal and informal learning, teachers create authentic STEM learning experiences that integrate IT concepts, skills, and applications into their classrooms, working with students to pursue research questions and deepen scientific and technical knowledge.  Using the same technologies, tools, and methods as scientists and STEM professionals, young people in grades Prek-12 explore their environment, conduct research, build programmable machines and tools, and create media in school and in community settings after school and during the summer.

NSF's mission calls for broadening the participation of groups, institutions, and geographic regions that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines, and STELAR and the ITEST program contribute to this mission. As of 2017, the ITEST community includes more than 230 unique institutions and partners including 2 and 4 year colleges & universities, informal science education organizations, PreK, elementary, middle and high schools, and community-based organizations with 34% of college/university partners being minority-serving institutions (MSIs).  Of the youth served by ITEST projects, 38% are from groups traditionally underrepresented in STEM with 56% of ITEST projects specifically targeting girls.

For more information about the STELAR center at EDC, contact PI Sarita Pillai at spillai@edc.org
